dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Tayyab's new fintech card is openly defying the core principles of Islamic finance by offering interest on customer balances.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tayyab's new fintech card is openly defying the core principles of Islamic finance by offering interest on customer balances.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Customer card balances are not used to generate interest income, and interest is not charged on them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's backed by some major players, like Kazpost Bank and Mastercard—that's a pretty bold move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's backed by some major players, like Kazpost Bank and Mastercard-that's a pretty bold move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The card was launched by the first Kazakhstan Islamic fintech Tayyab in partnership with Bank RBK and the VISA payment system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and the Shariyah Review Board in Malaysia has already condemned it, which uh, really highlights the controversy here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and the Shariyah Review Board in Malaysia has already condemned it, which uh, really highlights the controversy here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Compliance with the principles of Islamic finance is confirmed by the international Shariah Board Shariyah Review Bureau (Saudi Arabia), as well as the Spiritual Administration of the Muslims of Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, on one hand they're pitching it as a tool for the Islamic way of life—prayer times, halal cafe finders, Qibla compass…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, on one hand they're pitching it as a tool for the Islamic way of life-prayer times, halal cafe finders, Qibla compass...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The application also has prayer times and Azan, Qibla compass, Zikr counter, Zakat calculator and much more notes Daniyar Uspanov, Tayyab CEO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then they're also charging riba, which is explicitly forbidden. It feels like a real contradiction, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then they're also charging riba, which is explicitly forbidden. It feels like a real contradiction, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Customer card balances are not used to generate interest income, and interest is not charged on them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the CEO, Daniyar Uspanov, he's mentions all these faith-based features like a Zakat calculator and a Zikr counter…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the C E O, Daniyar Uspanov, he's mentions all these faith-based features like a Zakat calculator and a Zikr counter...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The application also has prayer times and Azan, Qibla compass, Zikr counter, Zakat calculator and much more notes Daniyar Uspanov, Tayyab CEO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but the financial model itself isn't Sharia-compliant. That's gonna alienate the very community they're targeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but the financial model itself isn't Sharia-compliant. That's gonna alienate the very community they're targeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Compliance with the principles of Islamic finance is confirmed by the international Shariah Board Shariyah Review Bureau (Saudi Arabia), as well as the Spiritual Administration of the Muslims of Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, the card restricts payments at casinos or alcohol sellers, which is consistent, but then they offer high interest? It's confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, the card restricts payments at casinos or alcohol sellers, which is consistent, but then they offer high interest? It's confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Customer card balances are not used to generate interest income, and interest is not charged on them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's only available in Kazakhstan, with withdrawals limited to Bank RBK ATMs—so fairly narrow usability too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's only available in Kazakhstan, with withdrawals limited to Bank R B K ATMs-so fairly narrow usability too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You can store money in four currencies Kazakhstan KZT, USD, EUR, RUB, and you can withdraw cash at any ATM in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They launched it around Ramadan starting August 20th, which is smart timing from a marketing perspective, but ethically questionable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They launched it around Ramadan starting August twentieth, which is smart timing from a marketing perspective, but ethically questionable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The launch of the project was timed to coincide with the main Islamic holiday Eid al-Adha, which falls on July 20 this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think investors like Abu Dhabi Fintech Ventures knew about this backlash risk?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think investors like Abu Dhabi Fintech Ventures knew about this backlash risk?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One of Tayyab's institutional investors is Dubai Fintech Ventures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to say, but partnering with Mastercard gives it legitimacy, even if the product itself is controversial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to say, but partnering with Mastercard gives it legitimacy, even if the product itself is controversial.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The card was launched by the first Kazakhstan Islamic fintech Tayyab in partnership with Bank RBK and the VISA payment system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, for a card that promotes an Islamic lifestyle, ignoring the ban on interest seems like a fundamental flaw.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, for a card that promotes an Islamic lifestyle, ignoring the ban on interest seems like a fundamental flaw.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Customer card balances are not used to generate interest income, and interest is not charged on them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It'll be interesting to see how users respond—will they prioritize convenience or principles?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It'll be interesting to see how users respond-will they prioritize convenience or principles?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: My guess? This might face serious pushback from devout customers, despite the useful app features.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: My guess? This might face serious pushback from devout customers, despite the useful app features.

artist_script:
HostA: Tayyab's new fintech card is openly defying the core principles of Islamic finance by offering interest on customer balances.
HostB: Yeah, and it’s backed by some major players, like Kazpost Bank and Mastercard—that’s a pretty bold move.
HostA: Exactly, and the Shariyah Review Board in Malaysia has already condemned it, which uh, really highlights the controversy here.
HostB: I mean, on one hand they’re pitching it as a tool for the Islamic way of life—prayer times, halal cafe finders, Qibla compass…
HostA: But then they’re also charging riba, which is explicitly forbidden. It feels like a real contradiction, you know?
HostB: And the CEO, Daniyar Uspanov, he’s mentions all these faith-based features like a Zakat calculator and a Zikr counter…
HostA: Right, but the financial model itself isn’t Sharia-compliant. That’s gonna alienate the very community they’re targeting.
HostB: Plus, the card restricts payments at casinos or alcohol sellers, which is consistent, but then they offer high interest? It’s confusing.
HostA: And it’s only available in Kazakhstan, with withdrawals limited to Bank RBK ATMs—so fairly narrow usability too.
HostB: They launched it around Ramadan starting August 20th, which is smart timing from a marketing perspective, but ethically questionable.
HostA: Do you think investors like Abu Dhabi Fintech Ventures knew about this backlash risk?
HostB: Hard to say, but partnering with Mastercard gives it legitimacy, even if the product itself is controversial.
HostA: Still, for a card that promotes an Islamic lifestyle, ignoring the ban on interest seems like a fundamental flaw.
HostB: Absolutely. It’ll be interesting to see how users respond—will they prioritize convenience or principles?
HostA: My guess? This might face serious pushback from devout customers, despite the useful app features.
